text: after having been first duly sworn, was deposed and says as follows: EXAMINATION
Mr. Burns, the oath you have taken is the same oath you would be given in a court of law and comes with the same penalties of perjury.  Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The court reporter is taking down every spoken word, so nods or head shakes cannot be transcribed by the court reporter.  Also, the court reporter can only take down what is being said by one person at a time.  I, therefore, ask that you wait until I finish my question before you give your answer, and I will try to provide the same courtesy to you.  Understood?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  If you don't understand a question, please let me know.  If you do answer my question, I will assume you understood and answered the question I asked.  Please do not guess in response to my questions.  However, I am entitled to your best estimate. Do you understand the difference between a guess and an estimate?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there any reason you cannot go forward today with providing your best testimony?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there any reason you cannot testify fully and truthfully today?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you under the influence of any drugs, alcohol or medications that may affect your ability to respond to my questions fully and truthfully?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  If you need to take a break, just feel free to let me know, okay?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I will.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you have any questions about the deposition process before we start?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I don't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I have, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you know then that your counsel may make objections during the deposition, and the purpose of that objection is for the judge to review the objection later.  So an objection is not instruction to not answer. Unless you are instructed not to answer the question by your counsel, please answer the question. Do you understand?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I understand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How many times have you been deposed before?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Six maybe, seven.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And are you currently a Boston Scientific employee?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were all of those other depositions related to your job as a Boston Scientific employee?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: All of my depositions have been except for one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What was that one?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: From a previous job in college, an accident at a bar that I was working at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And the depositions that took place while you were at Boston Scientific, did any of them relate to the Cognis and Teligen devices?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I don't believe so, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you ever testified at trial?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I have not, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Are you here -- are you appearing here at this deposition as a corporate representative of Boston Scientific on the topic of Boston Scientific's policies, procedures and practices as they existed from 2007 to 2009 for maintaining information regarding adverse events including the operation of the Lighthouse database?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the events in this case focus on the 2007 to 2009 time frame.  So absent me saying specifically otherwise, my questions relate to that time period. Do you understand?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I do understand, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What is your current position at Boston Scientific?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My current position is senior e-discovery manager.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what does that position entail?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I manage the preservation, collection and processing of data for Boston Scientific.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you work here in the Minneapolis/St. Paul area?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I do, yes, out of our Arden Hills office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what was your position from 2007 to 2009?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: To 2007 to 2009, I would have been a systems analyst on our e-discovery team.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At Boston Scientific?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How long have you been at Boston Scientific?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Since October 24th, 2005, full-time.  I was a contractor for six months prior to that as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when you were originally hired by the company, was it actually Guidant?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: It was, correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you were a systems analyst on the e-discovery team, what does -- what were your job functions?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My job functions would have been to collect data for cases that we were in litigation for.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So are you part of the legal department?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: During the 2007 to 2009 time frame we were part of the IT department.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So if you can start just from a very big picture, generally speaking, how did Boston Scientific, during this time period, maintain information about adverse events that happened with its devices?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So my understanding is that Boston Scientific leveraged either the RET system or the Lighthouse system to manage and summarize adverse events.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what was the RET system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: The RET system was a quality system that ran, I think from '96 was the start date of it through 2008, October of 2008, and that system contained all of the event summaries and also all of the MDR medical device reports, the 3500A data as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know, why did Boston Scientific transfer over from the RET system to the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope. You can answer that question.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I don't have an understanding specifically why they moved from one system to the other.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did Lighthouse have the same function as the RET system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is it has very similar functionality.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did it also contain the event summaries of adverse events and the Form 3500As?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How would information get into the -- either RET system or the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is that people in the quality team would enter that data into those systems.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And where would that information originate from?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: You know, I'm not a hundred percent sure on that, when it comes to the business side of that transaction, just that data would be ingested into that system.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So there's a kind of a document called a Product Experience Report; is that right?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Product Experience Report?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that term mean anything to you?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I've not heard of that term, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What about technical services, does that term mean anything to you?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Technical services is a department at formerly Guidant and now Boston Scientific.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And would technical services take in information about adverse events?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I can't say with a hundred percent confidence that that's the case.  I -- I can't say with confidence that's the case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know if a practicing physician experienced an adverse event and wanted to report it to Boston Scientific, what were the avenues by which that physician could do that?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: You know, I didn't -- I didn't prepare myself for that type of business questioning, so I don't -- I don't have an answer for that workflow of how a doctor would submit those types of events.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: When an adverse event happened and it was input into either the RET system or the Lighthouse system, would there be a PI number associated with that adverse event?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I have heard of a PI number, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I'm trying to understand what information would be associated with each adverse event and would it be associated with a PI number.  Those are two different questions.  Why don't we start with the -- I guess the first one about the PI number. Maybe the answer -- I'll just reask the question and you can answer. Was there a certain PI number associated with each adverse event in either the RET system or the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: You know, I can't say with a hundred percent confidence on that if that's the case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you know outside of the event summaries and the Form 3500As what information, other information about every adverse event was housed in those two systems?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Can you repeat that question?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  Outside of the event summaries and the Form 3500As, what information was associated with each adverse event in either the RET system of the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I don't have a specific data dictionary, if you will, of all the different fields or data points that were captured.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So I don't think I would know outside of those two things all of the different data points that would have been captured.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So if a call was placed to Boston Scientific to technical services, do you know whether that call would be recorded?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: My understanding is that the calls would have been recorded, so, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: And do you, know would those calls then -- the -- strike that. Would those recordings then be associated with that adverse event in the RET system or the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is those calls would be transcribed and associated back with those events.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So would the recording of the call be associated with the event or not?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: You're saying the actual audio of that?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is just the transcribed data would be associated with it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the recording existed in some other database?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: The recording would have existed in the Merlin system for a period of time --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: -- and then it would have dropped off.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how long it would have existed in the Merlin system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So it depends on the time frame, but it's either a 90-day or a 2-year retention, but both of which -- well, I'll leave it at that. It's either a 90-day or a 2-year retention.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so in the 2007 to 2009 time frame, were there some events -- strike that. Were there some calls that were recorded on a 90-day basis and some recorded on a 2-year basis?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is that some of them, during that time frame, would have been held for the 2 years and some would have been held for 90 days based off of the policy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what the policy is?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: It would have been the disaster recovery policy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know what -- strike that. Do you happen to know the number of that policy?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I do not, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know why some call recordings were kept for 2 years and some kept for 90 days?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I -- I -- I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was it possible to have kept those calls from the Merlin database for longer than those time periods if someone had wanted to keep them for longer?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Can you describe a little bit more what you're looking for there?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, sure.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Let's say that there was a patient who had a device implanted and there's an adverse event in which the patient died or had a serious injury, and before the call was deleted the patient, you know, had sued Boston Scientific.  Would it have been possible to keep that call recording if a litigation hold had been put into effect before the record was deleted?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So are you asking if it would have been possible to retain that tape, that -- that would have resided on for a longer period of time?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.  Well, no, I'm not asking specifically about the tape.  I'm asking about the information, the recorded audio.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I mean, my understanding is that the -- the actual text from the calls was what was kept as the record as opposed to the audio, so I -- I'm not sure, I mean, I'd be speculating if I were to -- to guess on anything on that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you don't know whether or not it was possible to keep the recorded audio information?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know who transcribed the calls?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I do not know whose function that was, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know whether it ever took longer than 90 days to transcribe the calls?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I -- I don't know of any that -- that had, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know whether there was any sort of quality control process to make sure that the transcribed transcriptions accurately reflected the audio recordings?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I do not, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So did these transcriptions from technical services calls become part of the event summary for an adverse event?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yeah, that's my understanding.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what other information was in the event summary?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: You know, I don't have a list of the fields or an intimate understanding of that business process.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How long does the event summary information stay in the Lighthouse database?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So the Lighthouse database is set without any auto purging.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: However, those records are -- supposedly have a lifetime of 75 years.  So at some point in 75 years they could be deleted.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know why the recorded audio information had a shorter retention time frame than the event summary information?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Again, my understanding is that the transcription of -- of that was the record as opposed to the audio portion of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I'm going to move to strike that answer, because that wasn't responsive to my question. I'm asking if you know the reason why the audio recording wasn't kept longer than the event summary information?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I -- I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Are the -- strike that. What is the time period during which the Form 3500As are kept?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: When you say, "Time period," are you referring to how long they're retained or are you --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes, I am referring to how long were they retained.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: And so could we back up just -- when you say -- are you talking about the data associated with the Form 3500A or are you talking about the specific Form 3500A.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would like to know about both.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So let's -- why don't we start, do you understand the process by which the Form 3500As were filled out?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: So my understanding is that data that is populated into that Form 3500A comes from the Lighthouse system, comes from that database, and those data points that are in there would follow that retention schedule of no purging and potentially a 75-year retention schedule.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Does that process happen automatically or does somebody pull up the information in Lighthouse and then fill out a form either by hand or on the computer?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So you're saying in order to create that --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: -- 3500A form?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm asking the way the data is populated that you referred to just now.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: So my understanding with the Lighthouse system is that you can manually create that 3500 form individually where you can bring up a record and generate that specific form.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: And then do you know what happens to that form once the data is populated?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Well, it -- it creates it, it takes about five to ten minutes for that PDF to be created per record.  It's individual, so you go through and you create it and then that is available for printing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know whether copies of those PDFs were retained?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is that they were not retained.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know the process by which the Form 3500As were submitted to the FDA?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is that those forms were batched together and sent through the Lighthouse system to the FDA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know whether any sort of copy of the batch was retained?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I do not.  My -- my understanding would be no, because we don't -- we don't have any of the PDFs that were associated with them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know how the information -- or strike that. Was the information from the RET system migrated to the Lighthouse system?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how that process happened?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So can you describe, when you say how it happened, are -- what are you looking for?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just looking for a general description.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So my understanding is a project team was pulled together to manage that data migration and that, you know, ultimately they came up with a plan to migrate data fields from RET into Lighthouse.  And I -- my understanding is that there was -- were some differences in the way that Lighthouse handled the product issue tab, and so the product issues from RET, back then it was called an event summary, that that was brought across a little differently in the form of a text file, as there was not a like for like fields to bring across.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how long the process took to migrate from RET to Lighthouse?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: You're talking -- are you asking about the entire project or just the actual data migration?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The entire project.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I'm not a hundred percent sure.  I know it's months at least.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know, were there any difficulties in migrating over the data from RET to Lighthouse?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I do not know of any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Were you involved in that process?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I was not, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know whether there are any regulations that govern the retention of information about adverse events?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to scope.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: I do not personally know of any, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Do you know of any other of Boston Scientific's policies that governed the data that was kept about the adverse event policy -- the adverse events?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Can you say that one more time, please?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know any other policies that Boston Scientific had that governed the retention of data about adverse events?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Outside of which policies?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mentioned the one about the disaster --
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Disaster recovery tapes?  Well, there would be a records retention policy that would govern records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that the title of that policy, record retention policy?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: It's pretty close to that.  It might be global records retention or something very similar.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Any other policies that you can think of at all?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Not that I can think of, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: And I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Let me just -- I just want to clarify something. EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: When you talked about the batch submission of MDR information to the FDA, did that take the form of -- of, let's say, like a hundred 3500A PDFs or was it just the data fields that were batched together and sent to the FDA?
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: My understanding was that was data fields that were sent over.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's --
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Can I just ask -- are you --
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: I'm done, yeah.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Okay.  Just one follow-up there. FURTHER EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So when you were describing to me earlier that a PDF would be printed out and submitted as part of the batch process, is that different from what you just told Mr. Robinson?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Yes, it -- so backing up, yeah, you can print out -- so I can go into Lighthouse, post that 2008 time frame, and I can print out a PDF of that individually for an MDR record.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that what happened when a Form 3500A was submitted to the FDA?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is that that would be set electronically in a batch file with a whole slew of fields that would represent that data to the FDA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So do you know what this -- strike that. I'm just -- let me explain my question.  I'm trying to understand what this would look like from the FDA's perspective receiving this. Would it be, you know, an e-mail with a hundred PDFs or would it be some sort of other file format?
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: My understanding is it's a batch file so, you know, similar to maybe a CSB file or an Excel spreadsheet that would have all the fields in there and then they would take that data and review that data.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: All right.  No further questions. FURTHER EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. ELLERBE

text: So to be clear, your understanding is we did not submit individual 3500A forms to the FDA?
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But if you want to go into the system and recreate one on a one-by-one basis, you're able to do that?
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: For the post-2008 data, correct.

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. ROBINSON

text: Okay.
